Question Text: Which of the following are examples of control plane operations? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Rate-limiting traffic so that the overall sending rate does not exceed a certain throughput.
b. Determining that a user's MAC address is authentic before allowing it to send traffic on the network.
c. Load balancing traffic across two output ports based on the hash of each packet's source IP address.
d. Determining the forwarding path that satisfies an access control policy.
e. Computing a shortest path routing tree.
LLM Explanation: Control plane operations involve making decisions about how to handle network traffic. This includes tasks like authentication, routing, and access control. Of the given choices, determining the forwarding path that satisfies an access control policy (d) and computing a shortest path routing tree (e) are control plane operations. They involve making high-level decisions about traffic handling. The other choices - rate limiting (a), MAC authentication (b), and load balancing (c) - are data plane operations that enforce the policies set by the control plane on a per-packet basis.
URLs: ['Software Defined Networks: A Comprehensive Approach by Paul Goransson and Chuck Black, Chapter 2: The Genesis of SDN', 'https://www.sdxcentral.com/networking/sdn/definitions/what-is-sdn-control-plane/', 'https://www.ciscopress.com/articles/article.asp?p=2995746&seqNum=2']
SM - Description: Reasoning error since authentication and access control is accepted to be a control plane operation in the explanation
Effect - Description of effects: Not knowing something that control plane can do

Question Text: What could be the operational steps behind the AT&T's IRSCP (a commercial version of the Routing Control Platform) for detecting malicious traffic? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. The controller sees all traffic passing through the network, detects an attack, and installs a null route to drop traffic at the entry point where the attack traffic is originating.
b. The end host changes its IP address so that it is no longer the target of the attack traffic.
c. A measurement system detects an attack, identifies the entry point of the attack, and instructs a controller to re-route traffic through a deep-packet inspection device.
d. A measurement system detects an attack, identifies the entry point of the attack, and instructs a controller to install a null route to drop traffic at the entry point where attack traffic is originating.
e. A victim end host sends an alert to an on-path firewall about the source and nature of an attack, at which point the firewall installs a null route to drop the traffic at the entry point where the attack is originating.
LLM Explanation: The correct steps for AT&T's IRSCP in detecting and mitigating malicious traffic are:c) A measurement system detects an attack, identifies the entry point of the attack, and instructs a controller to re-route traffic through a deep-packet inspection device. This allows detailed analysis of the malicious traffic.d) A measurement system detects an attack, identifies the entry point of the attack, and instructs a controller to install a null route to drop traffic at the entry point where attack traffic is originating. This stops the malicious traffic from propagating further into the network.The other options are incorrect because:a) The controller does not see all traffic and directly detect attacks. It relies on a separate measurement system. b) Changing the end host IP does not stop the attack traffic at the entry point.e) The end host does not send an alert directly to an on-path firewall to trigger mitigation.

Question Text: What are some example network management applications that become easier with control and data plane separation? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Improved interdomain routing security.
b. Customer-controlled egress selection.
c. Improved logging capabilities.
d. Planned maintenance of an edge router.
e. Forecasting of network capacity.
LLM Explanation: With the separation of control and data planes in SDN, certain network management tasks become easier. Customer-controlled egress selection (b) is simplified because the control plane can make forwarding decisions based on customer policies without needing to modify the data plane. Planned maintenance of an edge router (d) is also easier because the control plane can proactively reroute traffic away from the router to be serviced without impacting the data plane. While SDN may provide some benefits for the other options, they are not as directly enabled by control and data plane separation.
URLs: ['Software Defined Networks: A Comprehensive Approach by Paul Goransson and Chuck Black', 'SDN: Software Defined Networks by Thomas D. Nadeau and Ken Gray']
SM - Description: Improved interdomain routing security: With SDN, security policies can be more dynamically and centrally enforced, improving the security of routing between domains.
Effect - Description of effects: Not knowing that the separation can help with inter domain security

Question Text: What are some of the motivations for using Layer-2 forwarding in a data center? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Ability to use existing routing protocols to establish paths between hosts.
b. Easier configuration/administration, since there is no need to number hosts or configure subnets.
c. Better security properties.
d. Better scaling properties.
e. Better load balancing properties.
LLM Explanation: The main motivations for using Layer-2 forwarding in a data center are:b) Easier configuration and administration, since there is no need to assign IP addresses to hosts or configure IP subnets. With Layer-2 forwarding, hosts can be plugged in and communicate without additional IP-level configuration.  d) Better scaling properties. Layer-2 forwarding allows for larger Layer-2 domains and avoids the need for large IP routing tables. This can improve scalability, especially in large data centers with many hosts.
URLs: ['Software Defined Networking (SDN) Lecture Notes, Prof. Nick Feamster, University of Chicago', "Data Center Networking, Dinesh G. Dutt, O'Reilly Media, 2014"]
SM - Description: Either way there would be large tables
Effect - Description of effects: Can lead to switching to layer 2 networks unnecessarily

Question Text: How does the separation of the control and data plane make networking in data centers easier?
Choices:
a. Virtual machines can be migrated within the network without renumbering entire portions of the network or re-assigning network services to different IP addresses.
b. The control plane allows traffic to be forwarded using Layer 2 addresses, thus allowing automatic load balance across the topology.
c. The separation allows fewer switches to be used in the data center topology, thus lowering costs.
d. All routes can be controlled and monitored from a central point of control.
e. A network controller can permit the renumbering of end hosts to have topology-dependent Layer 2 MAC addresses.
LLM Explanation: Separating the control and data planes in a data center network enables easier management and flexibility. It allows virtual machines to be migrated within the network without the need to renumber network segments or re-assign services to new IP addresses (a). This is because the control plane can manage the network topology and addressing separately from the data plane forwarding. Additionally, having a logically centralized control plane allows all routes to be controlled and monitored from a single point (d), simplifying network operations and troubleshooting.
URLs: ['Software Defined Data Center Networking: Principles and Practice, Rajesh Kumar, Apress, 2020', 'Software Defined Networks: A Comprehensive Approach, Paul Goransson, Chuck Black, Morgan Kaufmann, 2016']
Effect - Description of effects: Not knowing something that controllers can do

Question Text: What are some examples of problems that can arise from consistency problems in the control plane, where a network has multiple controller replicas?
Choices:
a. A flood of traffic at the controller.
b. Inability to respond to link failures.
c. Incorrect security policies.
d. Incorrect operation when one controller fails.
e. Forwarding loops.
LLM Explanation: Consistency problems between multiple SDN controller replicas can lead to several issues:b) If controllers have inconsistent network state, they may be unable to properly respond to link failures and reroute traffic. c) Inconsistent security policies across controllers could allow traffic that should be blocked.d) If one controller fails, the others may operate incorrectly due to inconsistent state.e) Inconsistent forwarding rules could cause traffic to loop endlessly in the network.While a flood of traffic at the controller (a) is a potential SDN issue, it's not directly caused by control plane inconsistency.
SM - Description: One controller not being aware of the state is not due to having different replicas. Plus, even in a single controller, when the controller fails there are problems. If anything, multiple controllers help here
Sources Types: research paper, research paper, research paper
Effect - Description of effects: Debugging delay if you suspect some other issue

Question Text: What are some approaches to coping with inconsistency across controller replicas? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Running a consistency protocol across controller replicas.
b. Keeping a "hot spare" replica that has a complete view of the network state.
c. Only keeping a subset of the network state in memory at any time.
d. Using different controllers for independent parts of the network.
e. Having multiple controllers install forwarding table entries on the same router and resolving the conflict on the router itself.
LLM Explanation: Two effective approaches for handling inconsistency across SDN controller replicas are:a) Running a consistency protocol across the replicas to ensure they maintain a consistent view of the network state. This allows the replicas to synchronize state changes.d) Partitioning the network and having different controllers manage independent parts. This limits the scope of inconsistency to within each partition.The other options are not ideal because:b) Keeping a hot spare does not actively resolve inconsistencies between active replicas.c) Keeping only a subset of state in memory limits the controller's ability to make optimal decisions.e) Having routers resolve conflicts between multiple controller instructions adds complexity and unpredictability.
URLs: ['Software Defined Networks: A Comprehensive Approach by Paul Goransson and Chuck Black', 'https://www.opennetworking.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/TR-521_SDN_Architecture_issue_1.1.pdf']
SM - Description: I think the main problem is that it is not aware that real SDNs like ONIX employs method described in c and d to reduce the risk of inconsistent states. Reasoning error is secondary because it doesnâ€™t identify that the proposed solutions could help
Effect - Description of effects: Not knowing a few methods for reducing inconsistency

Question Text: What are some approaches to coping with scalability challenges associated with control and data plane separation? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Caching forwarding decisions in the data plane to reduce traffic at the controller.
b. Only performing control-plane operations for a limited set of network operations.
c. Eliminating redundant data structures.
d. Sending all traffic through the controller to minimize forwarding decisions that the routers and switches must make.
e. Running multiple controllers, and having each controller only manage a part of the network.
LLM Explanation: To cope with scalability challenges in SDN due to control and data plane separation, some effective approaches are:a) Caching forwarding decisions in the data plane. This reduces the traffic the controller needs to handle for repeated or similar flows.  c) Eliminating redundant data structures between the control and data planes to reduce overhead.e) Distributing the control plane across multiple controllers, each managing a portion of the network. This provides better scalability than a single centralized controller.Limiting control-plane operations to only certain functions (b) may help but is not a general scalability solution. Sending all traffic through the controller (d) would make the scalability problem worse, not better.
SM - Description: Missing information that RCP does this specifically for scalability
Effect - Description of effects: Not knowing a method for reducing inconsistency

Question Text: Which property guarantees that each RCP replica continues to install correct forwarding state in the network data plane, even in the case of a partition in the data plane?
Choices:
a. Each controller has a complete view of the portion of the network that it is controlling, and therefore can guarantee consistent routing within that partition.
b. The controller cannot see many of the routers in the network anyway, so there is no way for it to install incorrect routing state in the routers that it is not connected to.
c. The controllers are partitioned from the network routers, and the routers will fall back to running a distributed routing protocol.
d. Running the network from a single high-level control plane guarantees that network partitions and loops never occur in the first place.
LLM Explanation: In the case of a partition in the data plane, each controller has a complete view of the portion of the network it is controlling. This allows the controller to guarantee consistent routing within its partition, even if it is disconnected from other controllers or parts of the network. The controller can continue to install correct forwarding state in the routers it has visibility of and control over.
URLs: ['Software Defined Networks: A Comprehensive Approach by Paul Goransson and Chuck Black', 'Software-Defined Networking (SDN) with OpenFlow by Siamak Azodolmolky']
